description.narrative: New sustainable development solutions will be identified, aligned, tested and scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
1.1. Number of new data sources used at Country Office level 1.2. Diversity of different data sources used 1.3. Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4. Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses
2.1. Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2. Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3. Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4. Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies
3.1. Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2. Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network 3.3. Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network 3.4. Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem

1.1. 2 new data sources per year. 1.2. 3 different type of data sources per year 1.3. Identify 20 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4. 2 innovation methods per Action Plan

The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4. Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

1.1. • Due to a lack of information on the innovation systems within the country, the Lab conducted a rapid assessment (see attachment) to explore the current state of South Africa’s innovation ecosystem. The goal was to generate a source of data that identifies gaps within the ecosystem and can be used for possible enhancement • A novel source of information the Lab tapped into was the “Local Innovation Assessment Tool” (LIAT) developed by the Human Sciences Research Council), Africas largest dedicated social science and humanities research agency and policy think tank. LIAT gave the Lab access to community of practice brings together local and national actors with an interest in producing and sharing innovation information
1.2 • One source of data the Lab leveraged was the Innovation for Local Economic Development (ILED) strategy developed by the Department of Science and Innovation (DSI). The ILED strategy is anchored on the notion of local systems of innovation and production, emphasizing their importance in achieving inclusive Local Economic Development (LED) in South Africa. The strategy seeks to redefine LED policy and practice in the country by placing innovation at the centre of development, in pursuit of local economies that can support inclusive development and increase the prosperity of marginalised people, with a particular focus on distressed municipalities. • An “unusual” data source was provided by Rhodes University’s Technology Transfer Office (TTO). The TTO aims to successfully protect and commercialise the promising Intellectual Property • Emanating from the University, but in a context-appropriate way that will benefit the local socio-economic milieu as much as possible. This knowledge was used by the Lab to consider how IP should be handled regarding grassroots innovators. • Lastly, the Lab connected with the South Africa chapter of ENACTUS, a learning network of academic and student leaders that are unified by the vision to create a better, more sustainable world by developing the next generation of entrepreneurial leaders and social innovators. The network of student leaders allowed us access to communities that would have been difficult to enter.
1.3 • Due to the late onboarding of the Lab and our focus on our rapid assessment, we were only able to identify 10 potential solutions (see attachment)
1.4. • To overcome the resistance from the CO to the Accelerator Lab initiative, the Lab ran a series of workshops with the CO where we detailed the Lab’s purpose, its methodologies, and its potential value to various programmes. • To ensure that the lessons learned by the Lab would benefit CO colleagues, the Lab developed a fieldwork to aid in better engaging with local innovators. The guide would also serve as a tool that could be used beyond the life of the Lab.
2.1 • Each member of the Lab was able to publish one blog on the UNDP South Africa site (see Blog tracker)
2.2 • Our main learnings stemmed from the development of our rapid assessment which was developed in partnership the Department of Science and Innovation, a government entity.
2.3 • We had several meetings with the DSI where we outlined the methodologies of the Lab and their potential value to the broader innovation ecosystem. • We have also explained our methods to the Technology Innovation Agency (TIA), TIA is a national public entity that serves as the key institutional intervention to bridge the innovation chasm between research and development from higher education institutions, science councils, public entities, and private sector, and commercialisation. • AccLab South Africa also exhibited at the Department of Science and Innovation’s Science Forum and Innovation Bridge Conference
2.4 • Due to the late start of the Lab and the focus on overcoming resistance, we were not able to provide much actionable knowledge for ongoing CO projects.
3.1 • We participated in the regular weekly Global calls where we engaged with other Labs.
3.2 • We shared our Rapid Assessment broadly across the Lab network.
3.3 • The Lab was mentioned frequently on the CO’s social media i.e. our onboarding, launch. Development of rapid assessment, blog posts.
3.4 • Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem. • As our launch was attended by Minister of Higher Education, Science and Technology, it was covered on the DSI’s social media platforms. • The creation of the Lab was also mentioned on news platforms and various personal accounts of CO colleagues.

1.1. 5 new data sources per year 1.2. 6 different type of data sources per year 1.3. Identify 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4. 5 innovation methods per Action Plan
2.1. 6 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2. At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart.
2.3. At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4. At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO
3.1. The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 3.2. 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3. The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. 3.4. Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media.

1.1 • Through partnership, the Lab was able to tap into the data resources of the Water Research Commission (WRC), South Africa’s premier water knowledge hub active across the Innovation Value Chain that informs policy and decision-making in the water science sector. • The Lab collaborated with Tshimologong Digital Innovation Precinct on a COVID-19 related Makerthon. Tshimologong is a digital innovation ecosystem that propels entrepreneurship and grows the skills pipeline for the digital economy. Through this partnership we were able to tap into their rich data source on youth entrepreneurship. • The Lab was able to make use of the data sources provided by the Institute for Natural Resources (INR), a non-profit organization that works towards the wise use of natural resources in pursuit of sustainability for the good of the environment and the society, through multidisciplinary applied research. • Unconventionally, the Lab made use of the data resources of Al Baraka Bank and their Iqraa Trust, a Humanitarian organization that is tasked with the responsibilities of implementing some of its corporate social projects and initiatives and focuses on education, training, skills, development and health care and is active in all provinces of South Africa. • The Lab utilized data from the South African Red Cross Society to implement a social survey study during the COVID-19 lockdown.
1.2 • The Lab utilized mobile technology to deploy 50 youth, along with 5 Supervisors, into the communities in which they reside to register 6 500 households to receive emergency relief vouchers and to gather data on vulnerability and food security. • The Lab made use of UNICEF’s U-Report to empower youth to speak out on issues that they care about in their communities, encourage citizen-led development, and create positive change. • To assist in the COVID-19 relief efforts in the country, the Lab put out a call to makers, fabricators, and developers who wanted to assist with the country’s COVID-19 relief efforts by assisting in assembling innovations that fight the spread of this disease in a Makerthon. This event provided useful data in understanding the community of makers/innovators in the country. • As a source of data on the environment, the Lab participated in UNDP’s Mission 1.5 which uses mobile gaming technology to educate people about climate solutions and asks them to vote on the actions that they want to see happen. • As an experiment to gauge the CO’s online presence, the Lab actively engaged with the metrics provided by platform such as Google and Twitter to see the level of engagement people had with UNDP in the Country. • To understand the issue of Youth Unemployment in the country and identify ways in which to impact the problem, the Lab engaged heavily with the National Youth Policy developed by the South African government.
1.3 • The Lab was able to expand on its list of potential innovations by identifying 24 novel solutions.
1.4 • The Lab employed several innovation methods including: • Makerthon for COVID-19 innovations • Innovation Challenge with the Water Research Commission • Accelerator Lab Methods Workshop for stakeholders involved in Innovation for Local Economic Development (ILED), a government led strategy to seeks to redefine LED policy and practice in the country by placing innovation at the centre of development, in pursuit of local economies that can support inclusive development and increase the prosperity of marginalised people, with a particular focus on distressed municipalities. • 13 innovations underwent experimentation using various Innovation methods included Multi-site trials, cluster randomised trials, prototyping, Pre/Post-tests, hybrid tests and adaptive trials.
2.1 • Developed 8 blogs, 15 press releases, and multiple posts on social media and Microsoft Teams networks.
2.2 • 75% of our projects have had a public or private sector involvement including, but not limited to, partnerships with the Centre for Scientific and Industrial Research, the Water Research Commission, and the Department of Science and Innovation.
2.3 • Through partnership the Lab has instilled its methodologies to The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), South Africas central and premier scientific research and development organisation.
2.4 • At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. • We estimate that 75% of our learning challenges identified during 2020 have provided actionable knowledge to the CO.
3.1 • Lab members have participated in every weekly Global call • The Lab has also engaged with Colleagues in Namibia, Malaysia, Kenya, and the Philippines
3.2 • The Lab has produced weekly reflections that have been shared across the Lab network
3.3 • The Lab’s 8 blogs and 15 press releases have been shared across the CO social Platforms.
3.4 • The Lab’s efforts have been shared on the social platforms of the WRC, Tshimologong, INR, and various government departments.
Additional Results • Key frontier challenges identified, including Youth Unemployment and the Food, Water, Energy Nexus. • Acceleration activities identified through sense making, continuous communication, and active collaboration. • Collaborated on multiple projects internally, including collaborations with the programme areas Inclusive Growth and Energy and Environment. • Learning and actions identified through field research in Limpopo, KwaZulu Natal, Eastern Cape, and Northern Cape. • Developed initial version of fieldwork guide to identify solutions and capture novel information. • Experiments informed by solutions mapping and ethnographic insights. • Completed horizon scanning on continuous basis (though the pandemic limited this exercise). • Network of over 50 stakeholders and potential partners developed. • 1 collective intelligence study designed. • Developed framework to capture learning from experiments. • 13 innovations tested and provided with scaling options and support. • 16 innovations scaled after a successful cycle. • 3 key relationships established to scale innovations, including the Water Research Commission, Tshimologong Innovation Precinct, and the Institute for Natural Resources.

1.1. 5 new data sources per year. 1.2. 7 different type of data sources per year. 1.3. 25 new potential solutions per lab per year. 1.4. 8 innovation methods per Action Plan.
2.1. At least 10 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2. At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3. At least one government entity or partner has or is in the process of adopting an accelerator lab method. 2.4. At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.

The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media.
